item.title: Mattresses/Blankets/Bed Sofa Frame left for 6 months, 29th October
item.description:
Dear Bromley Council Environmental Services Team, ​I am writing to report a serious and long-standing case of fly-tipping/unauthorised waste dumping that has occurred at 92 Plaistow Lane, Katom House, Bromley, BR1 3FR. ​The waste was deliberately left and includes bulky items that cannot be disposed of through regular household refuse collections. The dumped items consist of: ​Mattresses ​Bed/Sofa frame ​Blankets ​A cooker/oven ​Crucially, these items have been present at this location since approximately April 2025. This duration represents a significant environmental and public health issue. ​ ​I request that this matter be urgently investigated and the waste removed as soon as possible, with a view to pursuing appropriate enforcement action against those responsible for the fly-tipping. ​Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Plaistow Lane, Plaistow, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Bollard knocked over, 29th October
item.description:
Metal bollard has been knocked out of place on the crossing. Since the crossings have been extended (bad decision) this has made visibility extremely limited on the crossing. Turning left off of Conduit Road into Bloomfield Road is more difficult too, not only because of the limited view of traffic coming up Bloomfield Road already, but also because of the now extended pavement which means you have to pull out of the junction further and at a tighter angle. The bollard needs replacing or the pavement reducing.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 18, Conduit Road, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Large cardboard boxes/ plastic, 29th October
item.description:
Southwark just removed similar items from this area a couple of days ago and again more dumped This situation needs to be rapidly escalated and fines issued- its costing residents through council tax etc and those responsible are not being held accountable-If one 'person' is allowed to get away with it then this encourages others to continue dumping.Southwark work hard cleaning the area up on a daily basis and still no apparent attempt to deal with those responsibile

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 3, Melon Road, Peckham, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Abandoned vehicle, 29th October
item.description:
Car has not moved in over a year, this is the second time I’ve reported in and I’m sure other people have reported this as well. MOT is expired. Clearly abandoned, at a loss as to why Greenwich Council seem unwilling to remove it. Parked opposite 33 and 31
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Wrottesley Road, Shooters Hill, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Dogs roaming in park late at night, 29th October
item.description:
Worryingly I was walking past Aldersbrook Pk late last night c10:20pm. As I passed two massive black dogs who could be on a banned list came chasing over towards us. It worries me someone is hanging around in the children's playground that late at night and no dogs are supposed to be in that section too. Can this park please be locked after dark or due to budget constraints assuming this has stopped? This would explain why some of the fake grass has been ripped up and the playground swing seats with teeth marks in them.
Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Aldersbrook Avenue, Southbury, London
Report on FixMyStreet
